questions.question: A U.S. citizen living in France earns $150,000 in wages from a French employer. For U.S. tax purposes, this income is:

options.B: Taxable because U.S. citizens are taxed on worldwide income
options.C: Taxable only if remitted to the U.S.
options.D: Exempt under the U.S.-France tax treaty

questions.explanation: U.S. citizens and residents are taxed on worldwide income regardless of where it is earned or where they reside. Relief from double taxation comes through the foreign earned income exclusion or foreign tax credit, not exemption.
questions.tip: U.S. citizens: Worldwide taxation. Location of income doesn't matter. Relief through FEIE or FTC.

questions.question: The foreign earned income exclusion (FEIE) for 2024 allows qualifying individuals to exclude approximately:
questions.explanation: The 2024 FEIE is $126,500 (indexed annually). This exclusion applies to foreign earned income for U.S. citizens or residents who meet either the bona fide residence test or physical presence test.
questions.tip: FEIE 2024: ~$126,500. Requires bona fide residence OR 330 days physical presence test.

questions.question: To meet the physical presence test for the foreign earned income exclusion, a taxpayer must be physically present in a foreign country for:

options.B: 330 full days in a 12-month period

questions.explanation: The physical presence test requires being physically present in a foreign country or countries for at least 330 full days during any 12 consecutive months. Partial days don't count, and the days need not be consecutive.
questions.tip: Physical presence: 330 FULL days in 12 months. Any 12-month period works.

questions.question: A taxpayer can claim the foreign tax credit for taxes paid on income that is also excluded under the foreign earned income exclusion:

options.A: True—both benefits can be claimed on the same income
options.B: False—cannot claim FTC on excluded income
options.C: Only if taxes exceed 25% of income

questions.explanation: No foreign tax credit can be claimed for taxes paid on income excluded under FEIE. Taxpayers must choose which benefit to apply. For high-tax countries, FTC may be more beneficial than FEIE.
questions.tip: FEIE and FTC: Cannot double-dip. Choose which benefit to claim on foreign income.

questions.question: A U.S. person must file FinCEN Form 114 (FBAR) if the aggregate value of foreign financial accounts exceeded what amount at any time during the year?
questions.explanation: FBAR filing is required if aggregate foreign financial accounts exceed $10,000 at any point during the year. This is separate from FATCA Form 8938, which has higher thresholds. Penalties for non-filing are severe.
questions.tip: FBAR threshold: $10,000 aggregate maximum value. Much lower than FATCA thresholds.

questions.question: In addition to the foreign earned income exclusion, a qualifying expatriate may also exclude or deduct:

options.B: Qualified foreign housing amounts above a base amount
options.D: Transportation to and from the U.S.

questions.explanation: The foreign housing exclusion (employees) or deduction (self-employed) allows exclusion of qualified housing expenses above a base amount (16% of FEIE) up to a cap (typically 30% of FEIE, higher in expensive cities).
questions.tip: Housing exclusion: Expenses above base amount (16% of FEIE), capped at 30% typically.

questions.question: A U.S. taxpayer living in the U.S. must file Form 8938 (Statement of Specified Foreign Financial Assets) if foreign assets exceed what threshold (unmarried, living in U.S.)?

options.B: $50,000 at year end or $75,000 at any time

questions.explanation: Form 8938 thresholds for unmarried taxpayers living in the U.S.: $50,000 on last day of year or $75,000 at any time during the year. Thresholds are higher for those living abroad or married filing jointly.
questions.tip: Form 8938 (U.S. resident, single): $50K year-end OR $75K any time. Higher thresholds abroad.

questions.question: A taxpayer has $100,000 foreign source income out of $200,000 total income. U.S. tax before credits is $50,000. Foreign taxes paid were $30,000. What is the maximum foreign tax credit?
questions.explanation: FTC limitation = U.S. tax × (foreign source income / worldwide income) = $50,000 × ($100,000 / $200,000) = $25,000. Even though $30,000 was paid, only $25,000 can be credited. The $5,000 excess carries over.
questions.tip: FTC limit = U.S. tax × (foreign income / total income). Excess credits carry 1 back, 10 forward.

questions.question: Which factor is most important in establishing bona fide residence in a foreign country for FEIE purposes?

options.B: Intent to make the foreign country the permanent home
options.D: Owning property in the foreign country

questions.explanation: Bona fide residence focuses on the taxpayer's intent and establishment of a home in the foreign country. Factors include maintaining a permanent home, family location, possessions, bank accounts, and social ties. Length of stay matters but intent is paramount.
questions.tip: Bona fide residence = intent + establishing home. All facts and circumstances matter.

questions.question: A U.S. person owns shares in a foreign mutual fund. This investment is likely classified as:

options.B: Passive foreign investment company (PFIC)

questions.explanation: Foreign mutual funds are typically PFICs because they meet the 75% passive income test or 50% passive assets test. PFIC rules impose harsh taxation—either current inclusion, excess distribution regime, or QEF/mark-to-market elections.
questions.tip: Foreign mutual funds = usually PFIC. Very unfavorable tax treatment without QEF election.

questions.question: A person is treated as a resident of both the U.S. and Canada under each country's domestic law. Under the U.S.-Canada tax treaty, where is residence determined?

options.B: Country where more time is spent
options.C: Tie-breaker rules based on permanent home, center of vital interests, habitual abode

questions.explanation: Tax treaties use tie-breaker rules: permanent home, center of vital interests (economic and personal ties), habitual abode, nationality. These are applied sequentially until residence is determined in one country.
questions.tip: Treaty tie-breaker: Permanent home → vital interests → habitual abode → nationality.

questions.question: For foreign tax credit purposes, foreign taxes are allocated to separate limitation categories ('baskets'). Which are the two main baskets?

options.B: General and passive category income

questions.explanation: The two main FTC baskets are general category income (most foreign source income) and passive category income (dividends, interest, rents, royalties from passive investments). Separate limitations prevent cross-crediting.
questions.tip: FTC baskets: General and passive. Cannot cross-credit between baskets.

questions.question: A U.S. citizen renounces citizenship with $5 million in unrealized gains on worldwide assets. Under the exit tax rules, what happens?

options.A: No tax until assets are sold
options.B: Mark-to-market taxation with exemption for first ~$866,000 (2024)

questions.explanation: Covered expatriates are subject to mark-to-market taxation on worldwide assets upon renouncing citizenship. The first ~$866,000 (2024, indexed) of gain is exempt. Deferred compensation and certain trust interests have special rules.
questions.tip: Exit tax: Mark-to-market with ~$866K exemption. Applies to 'covered expatriates.'

questions.question: A U.S. citizen living in Germany is self-employed and excludes $126,500 under FEIE. Is self-employment tax still owed?

options.A: No—FEIE excludes income from all U.S. taxes
options.B: Yes—FEIE only excludes income tax, not SE tax
options.C: Only if covered by U.S. Social Security

questions.explanation: FEIE only excludes income tax, not SE tax. However, totalization agreements with many countries (including Germany) prevent dual taxation. If covered by the foreign system under a totalization agreement, no U.S. SE tax is owed.
questions.tip: FEIE = income tax exclusion only. SE tax depends on totalization agreements.

questions.question: A U.S. beneficiary receives a $50,000 distribution from a foreign trust. Which form must be filed?

options.B: FBAR only

questions.explanation: Form 3520 must be filed by U.S. beneficiaries receiving distributions from foreign trusts. Penalties for non-filing can be severe (up to 35% of gross distribution). Form 3520-A is filed by the trust itself.
questions.tip: Foreign trust distribution to U.S. person = Form 3520 required. Severe penalties for non-filing.

questions.question: A U.S. resident performs services for a U.S. employer while physically present in Japan. The compensation is:

options.B: Foreign source income
options.C: Split based on time in each location

questions.explanation: Personal services income is sourced where the services are performed, regardless of employer location or residence. Services performed in Japan generate foreign source income, which may qualify for FEIE or affect FTC calculations.
questions.tip: Services income: Source = where performed. Not where employer located or payment received.

questions.question: A U.S. individual shareholder owns 30% of a controlled foreign corporation (CFC). They must include in income their share of:

options.B: Only distributed dividends
options.D: Nothing until the CFC is sold

questions.explanation: U.S. shareholders of CFCs must include their share of Subpart F income (certain passive and tainted income) and GILTI (Global Intangible Low-Taxed Income) currently, regardless of distribution. Individuals don't get the Section 250 GILTI deduction.
questions.tip: CFC individual shareholders: Include Subpart F + GILTI. No Section 250 deduction (unlike C corps).

questions.question: A taxpayer excludes $126,500 under FEIE and has $50,000 additional taxable income. At what rate is the $50,000 taxed?

options.B: At the rate that would apply if FEIE income were included

questions.explanation: FEIE-excluded income is used to determine the tax rate ('stacking rule'). The $50,000 is taxed as if it were the top portion of $176,500 total income, pushing it into higher brackets than if FEIE income were ignored.
questions.tip: FEIE stacking: Excluded income affects tax rate on remaining income. Higher effective rates.

questions.question: A green card holder who has never been to the U.S. in the current year has what U.S. tax filing obligation?

options.A: No filing required if not present in U.S.
options.B: Must file on worldwide income as a resident
options.C: Only U.S. source income is taxable
options.D: Filing required only if income exceeds $200,000

questions.explanation: Green card holders (lawful permanent residents) are U.S. tax residents regardless of physical presence. They must file and report worldwide income. Residence continues until the green card is officially abandoned or revoked.
questions.tip: Green card = U.S. tax resident. Worldwide income taxable regardless of where living.

questions.question: A foreign national was in the U.S. for 100 days in 2024, 120 days in 2023, and 150 days in 2022. Do they meet the substantial presence test for 2024?

options.B: No—calculated days are under 183
options.D: Yes—any year over 100 days triggers residence

questions.explanation: Substantial presence calculation: 2024 days (100 × 1) + 2023 days (120 × 1/3 = 40) + 2022 days (150 × 1/6 = 25) = 100 + 40 + 25 = 165 days. Must be 183+ to meet the test. This person is NOT a resident under this test.
questions.tip: SPT formula: Year 1 full + Year 2 ÷ 3 + Year 3 ÷ 6 ≥ 183 days.

questions.question: A U.S. citizen owns rental property in Spain generating $30,000 annual income. How is this reported?

options.A: Not reportable if reinvested in Spain
options.B: Schedule E with FTC available for Spanish taxes paid
options.D: Only if funds are brought to the U.S.

questions.explanation: Foreign rental income is reported on Schedule E like domestic rentals. Foreign taxes paid (Spanish income tax) generate a foreign tax credit. FATCA reporting (Form 8938) may also apply if the property meets asset thresholds.
questions.tip: Foreign rental: Schedule E reporting + FTC for foreign taxes. May also need Form 8938.

questions.question: A U.S. shareholder owns a PFIC and makes a QEF election. How is PFIC income taxed?

options.B: Currently on shareholder's pro-rata share of earnings

questions.explanation: A QEF election requires current inclusion of the shareholder's pro-rata share of PFIC ordinary earnings and net capital gains, similar to S corp treatment. This avoids the punitive excess distribution regime but requires annual PFIC statement from the company.
questions.tip: QEF: Current inclusion of PFIC earnings. Avoids harsh default rules but needs annual information.

questions.question: A U.S. person receives €50,000 when EUR/USD = 1.10. When converted to USD at EUR/USD = 1.20, what is the tax treatment?

options.B: $5,000 ordinary currency gain

questions.explanation: Foreign currency gain/loss on personal transactions is generally ordinary income/loss under Section 988. The €50,000 was worth $55,000 when received and $60,000 when converted, resulting in $5,000 ordinary gain.
questions.tip: Foreign currency gain/loss = ordinary income/loss (Section 988). Not capital gain.

questions.question: A taxpayer takes a position on their return based on a U.S. tax treaty that reduces U.S. tax. What disclosure is required?

options.A: No disclosure needed for treaty positions
options.B: Form 8833 Treaty-Based Return Position Disclosure
options.C: Disclosure only if tax savings exceed $10,000

questions.explanation: Form 8833 must be filed when a taxpayer takes a treaty-based return position that reduces their U.S. tax liability. Failure to disclose can result in penalties. Some routine positions are exempt from disclosure.
questions.tip: Treaty positions reducing U.S. tax require Form 8833 disclosure.

questions.question: A foreign national becomes a U.S. resident on July 1. For the year of arrival, they are:

options.B: Nonresident for full year
options.D: Can elect either status for full year

questions.explanation: In the year residency begins or ends, a taxpayer may have dual status: nonresident for part of the year and resident for the rest. Income during the nonresident period is U.S. source only; resident period includes worldwide income.
questions.tip: Dual status year: Split treatment. First-year election available to be treated as full-year resident.

questions.question: A U.S. person owns 15% of a CFC (confirmed to meet the CFC definition). Are they required to file Form 5471?

options.B: Yes—as a Category 5 filer (U.S. shareholder of a CFC)
options.C: Only if they acquired or disposed of stock during the year

questions.explanation: A U.S. person owning 10%+ of a CFC is a 'U.S. shareholder' and must file Form 5471 as a Category 5 filer. Category 5 applies to all U.S. shareholders (10%+ owners) of a CFC once the corporation meets the CFC definition (>50% U.S. shareholder ownership). Category 4 filers have additional 'control' requirements, but Category 5 covers all 10%+ U.S. shareholders of a confirmed CFC.
questions.tip: Form 5471 Category 5: All 10%+ U.S. shareholders of a CFC must file. Category 4 = controlling shareholders.

questions.question: A taxpayer claimed FEIE in prior years but now wants to revoke the election and use FTC instead. What is the consequence?

options.B: Must wait 5 years before re-electing FEIE without IRS consent
options.D: Revocation requires amended returns for all prior years

questions.explanation: Revoking FEIE is allowed, but if revoked, the taxpayer cannot re-elect FEIE for 5 years without IRS consent. This prevents year-by-year arbitrage between FEIE and FTC. Consider long-term planning before electing.
questions.tip: FEIE revocation: 5-year lockout from re-election without IRS consent.

questions.question: Which individual is NOT a 'covered expatriate' subject to the exit tax?

options.B: Average annual net income tax of $200,000 for 5 years
options.D: Net worth of $1 million with full tax compliance certification

questions.explanation: Covered expatriates meet ANY of: (1) net worth $2M+, (2) average annual tax liability $190K+ (2024) for 5 prior years, or (3) failure to certify tax compliance. Someone with $1M net worth and compliance certification is NOT covered.
questions.tip: Covered expatriate: $2M net worth OR ~$190K+ avg tax OR compliance failure.

questions.question: A taxpayer sells PFIC stock for $100,000 gain without a QEF or mark-to-market election. The holding period is 4 years. How is the gain taxed under the default regime?

options.B: Ordinary income at marginal rates
options.C: Allocated over holding period with interest charges at highest marginal rate

questions.explanation: The default PFIC regime allocates excess distributions (including gains) over the holding period. Prior year allocations are taxed at highest rate in effect for those years plus an interest charge. Current year allocation is ordinary income.
questions.tip: Default PFIC: Gain allocated over holding period + highest rates + interest charges. Very punitive.

questions.question: A U.S. citizen participates in a UK pension plan. For U.S. tax purposes, employer contributions to the plan are:

options.B: Currently taxable unless a treaty exemption applies

questions.explanation: Foreign pensions don't automatically qualify for U.S. tax deferral. Employer contributions may be currently taxable. Some treaties (like U.S.-UK) provide limited deferral. PFIC rules may also apply to foreign pension investments.
questions.tip: Foreign pensions: Generally taxable currently unless treaty provides deferral. Complex rules.

questions.question: An individual U.S. shareholder of a CFC makes a Section 962 election. What is the primary benefit?

options.B: Allows corporate tax rate (21%) and Section 250 deduction on CFC income
options.D: Converts ordinary income to capital gain

questions.explanation: Section 962 allows individuals to elect corporate treatment for Subpart F and GILTI inclusions, accessing the 21% rate and Section 250 deduction. However, subsequent distributions may be taxable as dividends, creating partial double taxation.
questions.tip: Section 962: Corporate rate + Section 250 for individuals. Watch for double tax on distributions.

questions.question: A taxpayer fails to file Form 5471 for their CFC ownership. What is the potential penalty?

options.B: $10,000 per form per year, plus additional monthly penalties

questions.explanation: Form 5471 non-filing penalty is $10,000 per form per year, plus $10,000 for each 30-day period (up to $50,000) after IRS notice. Statute of limitations may remain open. Reasonable cause exception available.
questions.tip: Form 5471 penalty: $10K + additional monthly penalties. Very serious. File even if late.

questions.question: A taxpayer owns PFIC stock with FMV of $500,000 at the beginning of the year and makes a mark-to-market election. At year-end, FMV is $550,000. What is the tax consequence?

options.B: $50,000 ordinary income

questions.explanation: Mark-to-market requires annual recognition of gain/loss on PFIC stock based on year-end FMV compared to the adjusted basis (which equals FMV at prior year-end under MTM). Gain is ordinary income; losses are ordinary (limited to prior MTM gains). Here: $550,000 (year-end FMV) - $500,000 (beginning-of-year adjusted basis) = $50,000 ordinary income.
questions.tip: PFIC MTM: Annual mark-to-market. Gains = ordinary income (not capital). Losses limited to prior MTM gains.

questions.question: An individual moving to the U.S. owns appreciated foreign assets. What planning strategy should be considered before becoming a U.S. resident?

options.A: Sell assets and recognize gain while still nonresident
options.B: Wait until U.S. resident to get stepped-up basis
options.C: Transfer assets to a foreign trust

questions.explanation: Pre-immigration planning involves recognizing gain on appreciated assets before becoming a U.S. resident (when only U.S. source income is taxable). This provides a 'step up' in basis. Once resident, worldwide gains are taxable.
questions.tip: Pre-immigration: Recognize foreign gains before U.S. residency. Creates basis step-up.

questions.question: A U.S. citizen working abroad in a high-tax country (45% rate) earns $200,000. Which strategy is most tax-efficient?

options.B: Claim FTC for all foreign taxes paid
options.C: Claim FEIE on first $126,500, FTC on excess
options.D: Skip both and pay U.S. tax only

questions.explanation: In high-tax countries, FTC is typically better than FEIE. With 45% foreign rate versus ~32% U.S. effective rate, FTC fully offsets U.S. tax with excess credits to carry over. FEIE would waste potential excess credits.
questions.tip: High-tax country: FTC usually better than FEIE. Preserves excess credit carryovers.
